questions.question_text: In Python, which expression checks whether the script returns a success status code when the Requests library is used?

discussion.content: A is the right answer.

Here's a list of all codes referenced by name in the .codes object:

https://2.python-requests.org/en/master/api/#status-code-lookup

"Some codes have multiple names, and both upper- and lower-case versions of the names are allowed. For example, codes.ok, codes.OK, and codes.okay all correspond to the HTTP status code 200."

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

response.status_code == requests.code.ok 
response + status_code from library equals requests imported . code from requets library and response code ok

correct, but not pythonic:

>>> if response.status_code == requests.codes.ok:
... print("ok")
...
ok

>>> if response.status_code:
... print("ok")
...
ok
>>>

comments.content: Wrong. Every status code, not only 200, would trigger that condition.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The script returns an output of 401. To use the supplied URL, an HTTP GET request must be sent with an Authorization header. The header value is a base64 encoded concatenation of the username and password. Which action must be taken to return an output of 200?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
it should be a GET method

The question is crazy and very bad worded.
If requests.login doesn''t exist, there should not be present any status code of 401, because the python script will not send anything, because it doesn't understand the syntax. 
Secondly, even with a get message there is no sense that the username:passoword should be json payload. It makes sense to use basic auth in this form or to use basic auth header in json format.

From my point of view this question is wrong

Selected Answer: D
This seems like a trick question. Simply changing "login" to "get" should fix it. You're still keeping the HTTPBasicAuth header intact while also sending the user/pass in the json payload according to this answer. Sending it in the payload shouldn't do anything since it's a simple GET. The payload will be ignored and the basic auth header will be used.
bad question. I agree with joephx08
Based on the status code of 401, i think the answer should be B; in case of GET issue, then status code should be 501.
requests library does not have LOGIN as a CRUD format

Selected Answer: D
It's D, altough I don't see why it should be passed in az a json object to HTTPBasicAuth.

Selected Answer: D
The question itself says "send a GET"

Selected Answer: D
I agreed.. It should be GET instead..
I think its D, because it should be a GET method

choices.B: Verify that the username and password values imported from the configuration file are still valid.
choices.A: Change the verify=False setting in the request to verify=True to enable HTTP Basic authentication.
choices.C: Insert an Authorization header with the values username:password from the supplied configuration file.
choices.D: Modify the method from LOGIN to GET and supply the username:password value as JSON payload.

questions.question_text: Before which process is code review performed when version control is used?

discussion.content: I think B
B. is correct.

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B
confusing expression!!!!!!!!! ah.......

Selected Answer: B
B
Before merge of code

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.
Create a new branch > Push code changes > Automated build and tests > Push code fixes > Automated build and test > Review and approve > Merge 
The code review is performed before Merge the code.
B is correct

D is Correct, The question asks what happens before code review. Why would you merge and then review the code, imagine merging with the production branch then reviewing it.
Branching -> Review -> Merge Request

comments.content: Then based on ur own answer, it is D. Read again the question.
My bad, my train of thought was you wouldnt straight up merge then review. B was just worded weird should be merge request, also messed up my innitial comment
Sorry, the correct answer is B

discussion.content:
B IS THE CORRECT.
Check this link to see how Git operations fit on the Pipeline of CI/CD

I used to think B, but after think twice:

+ Master branch is for production.
+ Branch is for New features and Fixes, which could be considered as code review )

For that reason, D is the correct answer

comments.content: Check my other post, i determine that B is correct

discussion.content:
Branching -> Code Review -> Merging
B is correct
Should be B
I think it is B.

It seems to be B.
https://medium.com/palantir/code-review-best-practices-19e02780015f#:~:text=When%20to%20review,changes%20since%20the%20last%20release.
I think B is correct
D.
I would also say B

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A Python code has been written to query a device. The executed code results in the error shown. Which action resolves the problem?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
You get the "NameError" whether the "requests" module is installed or not, if the "requests" module is not imported. If you try to import the "requests" module when it's not installed, you get the "ModuleNotFoundError".

C.
Please check out this StackOverflow code.
For me worked when I tried this example.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26895371/nameerror-name-requests-is-not-defined

comments.content: U still have to import requests module

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. import requests

Selected Answer: D
It's D

Selected Answer: D
Could it be C or D.. 
C. pip install requests - cause the requests may not yet be installed
D. import requests - cause the requests library isn't being imported to use
But since the question is not showing the import requests, it might be D.
Answer is B I think. GET needs to be all caps.
I think it's D, but it could be C.
Stateless is the correct answer.
Yeah stateless is correct

Selected Answer: B
That is the definition of stateless

Selected Answer: B
B is correct:
RESTful constraints are described as follows:

- Client/server - clients and servers are fully separated and communicate only via the RESTful interface.
- Stateless - no client context or state is stored on the server between requests, and each client request must contain all of the information needed for the server to service the request.
- Cacheable - clients can cache responses, and servers must define the cacheability of the response.
- Layered - a client should not be able to tell whether it is connected to a server or to an intermediate that provides functionality such as security, caching, or load-balancing.
- Code on Demand (Optional) - servers can at times extend the capabilities of a client through the transfer of executable code or scripts.
- Uniform Interface - both client and server must adhere to a uniform interface that allows for the independent development of functionality.
- Resource Identification - individual resources are identified using URIs in requests. Representations of resources are distinct from the actual resources and may be provided in formats such as HTML, XML, or JSON.

questions.question_text: Which REST architectural constraint indicates that no client context should be stored on the server between requests?
